content.title: Lymphatic Anatomy
content.summary: The lymphatic system is a unidirectional network of vessels and nodes that collects interstitial fluid (lymph), filters it through lymph nodes, and returns it to the venous circulation. Understanding lymphatic anatomy is essential for managing lymphedema and planning oncologic surgery.
content.definition: The anatomical network of lymphatic capillaries, collecting vessels, lymph nodes, trunks, and ducts that drain interstitial fluid and immune cells back to the venous circulation

lymphatic_capillaries.structure: Blind-ended, single endothelial layer with button-like junctions
characteristics: Anchored to surrounding tissue by filaments

collecting_vessels.structure: Similar to veins - smooth muscle, valves, adventitia
collecting_vessels.lymphangions: Functional units between valves that contract rhythmically

lymph_nodes.structure: Encapsulated filtering stations with cortex and medulla
lymph_nodes.distribution: 300-500 nodes total, clustered in specific regions

lymphatic_trunks.lumbar_trunks: Drain lower extremities, pelvis, kidneys → cisterna chyli

thoracic_duct.course: Ascends through aortic hiatus, posterior mediastinum
thoracic_duct.drainage: Left side of head/neck, left arm, both legs, abdomen

right_lymphatic_duct.drainage: Right side of head/neck, right arm, right thorax

deep_system.follows: Deep veins along tibial and femoral vessels

upper_extremity.clinical_note: Axillary node dissection commonly causes lymphedema

clinical_relevance.lymphatic_sparing: Techniques to preserve collectors when possible
clinical_relevance.sentinel_node_concept: First node to receive drainage from tumor area

imaging_modalities.lymphoscintigraphy: Nuclear medicine, gold standard for function

definition.@value: The anatomical structure of the lymphatic system including capillaries, vessels, nodes, and major ducts

learning_objectives: Describe the components of the lymphatic system from capillaries to ducts
Trace the drainage pathways of the lower and upper extremities
Explain the course and territories of the thoracic and right lymphatic ducts
Understand the role of lymphangions in lymph propulsion
Apply lymphatic anatomy to understanding lymphedema patterns
clinical_pearls: Thoracic duct drains everything except right upper quadrant of body
80% of lymph drainage in extremities is via superficial system
Axillary dissection is the most common cause of secondary lymphedema
Lymphangions contract 6-10 times per minute (intrinsic pump)
2-4 liters of lymph returned to circulation daily
